string-array.name: data_fragments
string-array.item: { _id : \"3\", name : \"To Be or Not To Be\", layout : \"fragment_to_be_or_not_to_be\" }
{ _id : \"6\", name : \"And Let\'s Group Them Verbs\", layout : \"fragment_lets_group_them\" }

string-array.name: table_contents
string-array.item: { column : \"_id\", type : \"INTEGER\", extra : \"PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT NOT NULL\" }

string-array.name: data_contents
string-array.item: { fragment_id : \"1\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"Hello World! こんにちわ！ Welcome to Benkyou no Nikki. This app is written to help me review my notes from when I was studying Japanese.\" }
{ fragment_id : \"1\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"Sources: \n 1) Human Japanese 2.0 by Brak Software, Inc\" }

{ fragment_id : \"3\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"In the example above, the verb たべます, which means eats, is put at the end of the sentence. This rule holds true for every Japanese sentence.\n\nMore examples below:\" }
{ fragment_id : \"6\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"We\'ll start with the third group because this group contains only 2 verbs. These verbs are called irregular verbs.\" }

{ fragment_id : \"6\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"The verbs in this group are called Ru-verbs or Vowel-stem-verbs or いちだんどうし(ichidan-doushi). Notice the \'e\' vowel right before ます(masu).\" }
{ fragment_id : \"6\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"However, there are some exceptions. Some of the verbs have the \'i\' vowel right before ます(masu).\" }

{ fragment_id : \"6\", style : \"FragmentLeftTextView\", content : \"The verbs in this group are called U-verbs or Consonant-stem-verbs or ごだんどうし(godan-doushi). All the verbs have the \'i\' vowel right before ます(masu).\" }

{ fragment_id : \"9\", style : \"FragmentCenterTextView\", content : \"じしょ (jisho) means dictionary in Japanese. If you search in the dictionary, you will not find the ます ending verbs - you will have to use the dictionary form. Why are we only learning this form now? Well, I actually learnt the dictionary form first before the other forms, but I think learning the ます form first makes it much easier to recognize and memorize groups I, II and III.\" }
{ fragment_id : \"10\", style : \"FragmentCenterTextView\", content : \"This is the plain past form. To conjugate a verb to ta form, just change て to た and で to だ from its te form.\" }

{ fragment_id : \"11\", style : \"FragmentCenterTextView\", content : \"The ふつう (general) form is nothing but the じしょ (dictionary) form, ない (nai) form, た form and the past form of ない (nai) form used on どうし (verbs), いけいようし (i-adjectives), なけいようし (na-adjectives) and めいし (nouns).\" }
